defs.docs: # Deadpool [![Latest Version](https://img.shields.io/crates/v/deadpool.svg)](https://crates.io/crates/deadpool) [![Build Status](https://img.shields.io/github/workflow/status/bikeshedder/deadpool/Rust)](https://github.com/bikeshedder/deadpool/actions?query=workflow%3ARust)

attributes.value: / Deadpool is a dead simple async pool for connections and objects
/   - Creates and recycles objects as needed
/   - Enabled via the `managed` feature in your `Cargo.toml`
/   - All objects either need to to be created by the user and added to the
/     pool manually. It is also possible to create a pool from an existing
/   - Enabled via the `unmanaged` feature in your `Cargo.toml`
/ This is the obvious choice for connection pools of any kind. Deadpool already
/ comes with a couple of [database connection pools](#database-connection-pools)
/ which work out of the box.
/     async fn recycle(&self, conn: &mut Computer) -> deadpool::managed::RecycleResult<Error> {
/ Deadpool supports various database backends by implementing the
/ ### Reasons for yet another connection pool
/ Deadpool is by no means the only pool implementation available. It does
/ things a little different and that is the main reason for it to exist:
/ - **Deadpool is compatible with any executor.** Objects are returned to the
/   pool using the `Drop` trait. The health of those objects is checked upon
/   next retrieval and not when they are returned. Deadpool never performs any
/   actions in the background. This is the reason why deadpool does not need
/   to spawn futures and does not rely on a background thread or task of any
/ - **Identical startup and runtime behaviour**. When writing long running
/   application there usually should be no difference between startup and
/   runtime if a database connection is temporarily not available. Nobody
/   would expect an application to crash if the database becomes unavailable
/   at runtime. So it should not crash on startup either. Creating the pool
/   never fails and errors are only ever returned when calling `Pool::get()`.
/   If you really want your application to crash on startup if objects can
/   not be created on startup simply call
/ - **Deadpool is fast.** The code which returns connections to the pool
/   contains no blocking code and retrival uses only one locking primitive.
/ - **Deadpool is simple.** Dead simple. There is very little API surface.
/   The actual code is barely 100 lines of code and lives in the two functions
/ ### Differences to other connection pool implementations
/   options but only provides a synchroneous interface.
/   interface and provides the same configuration options as `r2d2`. It
/   depends on the tokio executor though and the code is more complex.
/   interface and provides a lot more configuration options. It requires an
/   executor though and the code is a lot more complex.
/ An unmanaged pool is useful when you can't write a manager for the objects
/ you want to pool or simply don't want to. This pool implementation is slightly
/ faster than the managed pool because it does not use a `Manager` trait to
/ `create` and `recycle` objects but leaves it up to the user.

defs.name: managed
defs.docs:
This module contains the managed version of the pool. Managed meaning
 that it requires a `Manager` trait which is responsible for creating
 and recycling objects as they are needed.

defs.name: from_env
defs.docs:
Create pool config by reading it from the environment.
 ## Example environment
 ```env
 POOL_MAX_SIZE = 1s
 POOL_TIMEOUTS_WAIT = 1s
 POOL_TIMEOUTS_CREATE = 1s
 POOL_TIMEOUTS_RECYCLE = 1s
 ```
 ## Example usage
 ```rust,ignore
 Config::from_env("POOL")
 ```

attributes.value: / Create pool config by reading it from the environment.

deprecated(since = "0.5.2", note =
             "Please embed this structure in your own config structure and use `config::Config` directly.")

defs.name: Manager
defs.docs: This trait is used to `create` new objects or `recycle` existing ones.

defs.name: create
defs.value:
pub fn create<'life0, 'async_trait>(&'life0 Self)
->
    ::core::pin::Pin<Box<::core::future::Future<Output = Result<T, E>> +
                         ::core::marker::Send + 'async_trait>> where
'life0:'async_trait, Self: 'async_trait
defs.docs: Create a new instance of `T`

defs.name: recycle
defs.value:
pub fn recycle<'life0, 'life1, 'async_trait>(&'life0 Self, &'life1 mut T)
->
    ::core::pin::Pin<Box<::core::future::Future<Output = RecycleResult<E>> +
                         ::core::marker::Send + 'async_trait>> where
'life0:'async_trait, 'life1:'async_trait, Self: 'async_trait
defs.docs:
Try to recycle an instance of `T` returning None` if the
 object could not be recycled.

defs.name: Object
defs.docs:
A wrapper around the actual pooled object which implements the traits
 `Deref`, `DerefMut` and `Drop`. Use this object just as if it was of type
 `T` and upon leaving scope the `drop` function will take care of
 returning it to the pool.

/ `T` and upon leaving scope the `drop` function will take care of

defs.name: take
defs.docs:
Take this object from the pool permanently. This reduces the size of
 the pool.

defs.name: Pool

/ and uses reference counting for its internal state.

defs.name: new
defs.value:
pub fn new<impl Manager<T, E> + Send + Sync + 'static: Manager<T, E> + Send +
           Sync + 'static>(impl Manager<T, E> + Send + Sync + 'static, usize)
-> Pool<T, E>
defs.docs:
Create new connection pool with a given `manager` and `max_size`.
 The `manager` is used to create and recycle objects and `max_size`
 is the maximum number of objects ever created.

attributes.value: / Create new connection pool with a given `manager` and `max_size`.
/ The `manager` is used to create and recycle objects and `max_size`
/ is the maximum number of objects ever created.

defs.name: from_config

                   Send + Sync +
                   'static>(impl Manager<T, E> + Send + Sync + 'static,
                            PoolConfig) -> Pool<T, E>
defs.docs:
Create new connection pool with a given `manager` and `config`.
 The `manager` is used to create and recycle objects and `max_size`
 is the maximum number of objects ever created.

defs.name: available
defs.docs:
The number of available objects in the pool. If there are no
 objects in the pool this number can become negative and stores the
 number of futures waiting for an object.
